awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Predicting Real-time Population Behavior during Hurricanes Synthesizing Data from Transportation Systems and Social Media
awd_abstract_narration:
This project develops new methods to forecast real-time population behavior during natural disasters, potentially transforming the current state of emergency response in a cost-effective way. To understand how individuals, infrastructure systems, and emergency services should prepare and respond during such disasters, this project utilizes data available from multiple sources including from transportation systems and online social media. Using innovative data science approaches to integrate data from multiple sources increases the quality of the data available for emergency response prediction and improved evacuation traffic management. Research outputs will be shared with the practitioner community to facilitate improved decision making for emergency agencies in hurricane evacuation and disaster management. This scientific research contribution thus supports NSF's mission to promote the progress of science and to advance our national welfare. In this case, the benefits will be insights to improve emergency response, which will save lives, economic losses, and reduce panic, anger and confusion during a future event.

The project combines heterogeneous data sources from transportation systems and social media, in a unified framework-providing better information for modeling dynamic population behavior during hurricanes. To accurately predict evacuation demand, this project leverages large-scale real-time data, rarely used by existing emergency decision support tools. It advances the data science of disaster management by developing novel information fusion techniques to represent population and its behavior while employing government survey and social media data, text-mining approaches to extract evacuation intent from social media data, and evacuation traffic prediction models to optimize transportation resources. Through its innovative data gathering and modeling approaches, this project will enhance our ability to deal with future hurricanes. The project engages a broader participation of graduate and undergraduate students including from under-represented groups and plans a broader dissemination of results to traffic engineers and emergency management officials from local counties and cities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Evacuations play a critical role in saving human lives during hurricanes. But evacuation decision-making is a complex dynamic process, often studied using post-hurricane survey data. As a result, anticipating evacuation traffic in real time is difficult due to high uncertainties in human behavior and hurricane intensity. Social media data can be used to predict evacuation demand in real time to enhance evacuation traffic prediction. The project focused on developing new methods to predict real-time population behavior from social media data and traffic flows in transportation systems during hurricane evacuations, to transform the current state of evacuation traffic management.

The project made multiple important advances. First, as technology and the role of social media evolve in society, we need to understand the socio-technical aspects of social media’s employment during disasters. An analysis of after action reports on Hurricane Irma (September 2017) by governments and a focus-group session with emergency management practitioners revealed several challenges of using social media for crisis communication at a local level including: insufficient staffing, space for staffing, funding, and technical equipment; coordination issues across multiple platforms and accounts within the county; and over-reliance on social media, which resulted in portions of the population being without critical information. Also, it is important to understand how people interact with different emergency management agencies on social media platforms. We analyzed hurricane-related posts in Twitter made by different federal, state and regional organizations during Hurricane Irma. We found that different types of local agencies played a leading role to address the varying needs of a community. Emergency management agencies can characterize, monitor, and improve public engagement of their crisis communication efforts in social media and eliminate public complacency during disaster response.

Second, to better understand evacuation behavior from social media data, multiple data science methods have been developed in this project. For instance, we trained a data-driven model from geo-located tweets to predict what activities are made by individuals, when they decide to evacuate, and where they evacuate to. Using input variables such as evacuation context, time to landfall, type of evacuation order, and the distance from home, the method can predict evacuation behavior in real time from Twitter data. In another study, we trained a model to distinguish tweets expressing positive evacuation decisions from both negative and irrelevant ones. We found that tweets expressing an intent to evacuate peak well before other measures, suggesting that they may serve as a leading indicator of evacuation behavior. As an alternative to Twitter data, we analyzed Facebook population data to understand trends of evacuation behavior over time and space for Pinellas and Lee Counties in Florida during Hurricane Ian (September 2022). The results revealed greater evacuation rates for areas located far from shelter locations and with higher percentages of mobile homes, old people, and  houses built before 2000 and lower evacuation rates for areas with higher percentages of homeowners and Hispanic populations. Lee County was associated with lower evacuation rates compared to Pinellas County. The analysis showed the value of another social media data source from Facebook to understand evacuation behavior in an unfolding hurricane at a high spatial resolution.

Third, one major limitation of using social media data is that they are often associated with selection biases and population representativeness issues. To overcome this challenge, we developed a new algorithm to combine heterogeneous data sources from travel demand databases and social media platforms. Specifically, Twitter data of 2300 users were merged with a representative National Household Travel Survey (NHTS) data, thus creating a hybrid dataset to improve the representativeness as well as provide a rich set of variables for a better understanding of evacuation behavior. Since traditional surveys are infrequent, costly, and often performed at a post-hurricane period, these data science methods to utilize social media data will become useful for predicting evacuation demand more accurately as a hurricane unfolds in real time.

Fourth, increased demand for evacuation causes significant traffic congestion in highways. An accurate traffic prediction model is needed for deploying pro-active traffic management strategies. To this end, we developed a new data-driven traffic prediction model that was first trained and tested on the data gathered from hundreds of traffic detectors during the evacuation period of Hurricane Irma. The test results showed that the model outperforms existing models for predicting evacuation traffic. Later, this data-driven approach was extended by adding Facebook movement data as input and tested to predict evacuation traffic of Hurricane Ian. Adding Facebook movement data further improved model performance.

In summary, the project produced data, methods, and insights that will significantly enhance our ability to predict evacuation demand in real time for better hurricane response such as targeted warning dissemination. The project also advanced methods to better anticipate traffic congestion for taking proactive measures that would reduce delays during evacuation, thereby reduce anxieties and panic of evacuees.
